comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
The Obelisk represented the amount of gold found in Australia, and the black stripes on the base was coal from various coal fields in NSW.
" ... near them [the flight of steps] is a gigantic coal and gold obelisk, the upper and gilded portion representing the yield of the various colonies, Victoria at the base having the lion's share. Then follow New South Wales, New Zealand, and Queensland, after which a small slice near the apex is marked "S.A.", meaning, I suppose, South Australia; the point of the obelisk being marked "T.", which I presume is intended to represent Tasmania's yield of the precious metal. ... " From the South Australian Advertiser - 24/09/1879 p.5 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/29375259

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The obelisk looks like it was made in paper mache, thanks for the info though BCA.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hpeters] I like to imagine it when I drive past. It's interesting that it extended over the area where the present expressway sits. It was truly huge for it's day if it was much larger than the QVB as the article says.
